segment.source: Add a splash screen
segment.target: Add a splash screen

segment.source: Set your app's splash screen image and background color using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Set your app's splash screen image and background color using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Add a splash screen
segment.target: Add a splash screen

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Set your app's splash screen image and background color using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Set your app's splash screen image and background color using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Set the splash screen image and background color in Visual Studio 2015
segment.target: Set the splash screen image and background color in Visual Studio 2015

segment.source: When you use a Visual Studio 2015 template to create your app, a default image is added to your project and set as the splash screen image.
segment.target: When you use a Visual Studio 2015 template to create your app, a default image is added to your project and set as the splash screen image.

segment.source: The background color for your splash screen defaults to a light gray.
segment.target: The background color for your splash screen defaults to a light gray.

segment.source: If you want to change the default image or color of your app's splash screen, follow these steps:
segment.target: If you want to change the default image or color of your app's splash screen, follow these steps:

segment.source: Open your existing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Open your existing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: From Solution Explorer, open the "Package.appxmanifest" file.
segment.target: From Solution Explorer, open the "Package.appxmanifest" file.

segment.source: You can also open this file from the menu bar by choosing ProjectStoreEdit App Manifest.
segment.target: You can also open this file from the menu bar by choosing ProjectStoreEdit App Manifest.

segment.source: Open the Visual Assets tab and select Splash Screen from the All Image Assets pane on the left side of the "Package.appxmanifest" window.
segment.target: Open the Visual Assets tab and select Splash Screen from the All Image Assets pane on the left side of the "Package.appxmanifest" window.

segment.source: If you're changing your splash screen for the first time, you'll see the "AssetsSplashScreen.png" path in the Splash Screen field.
segment.target: If you're changing your splash screen for the first time, you'll see the "AssetsSplashScreen.png" path in the Splash Screen field.

segment.source: The following screen shot shows the "Package.appxmanifest" window in Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: The following screen shot shows the "Package.appxmanifest" window in Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Depending on the type of project, you will see a slightly different set of visual assets.
segment.target: Depending on the type of project, you will see a slightly different set of visual assets.

segment.source: a screen shot of the "package.appxmanifest" window in visual studio 2013
segment.target: a screen shot of the "package.appxmanifest" window in visual studio 2013

segment.source: If you open "Package.appxmanifest" in a text editor, the SplashScreen element appears as a child of the VisualElements element.
segment.target: If you open "Package.appxmanifest" in a text editor, the SplashScreen element appears as a child of the VisualElements element.

segment.source: The default splash screen markup in the manifest file looks like this in a text editor:
segment.target: The default splash screen markup in the manifest file looks like this in a text editor:

segment.source: To select a new splash screen image for a UWP app, press the button with an ellipsis that appears next to the 1240 x 600 px label below Scaled Assets.
segment.target: To select a new splash screen image for a UWP app, press the button with an ellipsis that appears next to the 1240 x 600 px label below Scaled Assets.

segment.source: Choose the 1240 x 600 pixel image (.png, .jpg, or .jpeg) you'd like to use for your splash screen image.
segment.target: Choose the 1240 x 600 pixel image (.png, .jpg, or .jpeg) you'd like to use for your splash screen image.

segment.source: Important The splash screen image you choose must be 620 x 300 pixels using a 1x scaling factor.
segment.target: Important The splash screen image you choose must be 620 x 300 pixels using a 1x scaling factor.

segment.source: Also, when designing your splash screen, note that it is smaller than the screen, and centered.
segment.target: Also, when designing your splash screen, note that it is smaller than the screen, and centered.

segment.source: It does not fill the screen like a splash screen for a Windows Phone Store app does.
segment.target: It does not fill the screen like a splash screen for a Windows Phone Store app does.

segment.source: To select a new splash screen image for a Windows Phone Store app, press the button with an ellipsis that appears next to the 1152 x 1920 px label below Scaled Assets.
segment.target: To select a new splash screen image for a Windows Phone Store app, press the button with an ellipsis that appears next to the 1152 x 1920 px label below Scaled Assets.

segment.source: Choose the 1152 x 1920 pixel image (.png, .jpg, or .jpeg) you'd like to use for your splash screen image.
segment.target: Choose the 1152 x 1920 pixel image (.png, .jpg, or .jpeg) you'd like to use for your splash screen image.

segment.source: Important The splash screen image you choose must be 1152 x 1920 pixels which is the correct size for a 2.4x scaling factor.
segment.target: Important The splash screen image you choose must be 1152 x 1920 pixels which is the correct size for a 2.4x scaling factor.

segment.source: If this is the only asset you provide then it will be scaled down for 1.4x and 1x scaling factors.
segment.target: If this is the only asset you provide then it will be scaled down for 1.4x and 1x scaling factors.

segment.source: In the Background Color field of the Splash Screen section, set the background color displayed with your splash screen image.
segment.target: In the Background Color field of the Splash Screen section, set the background color displayed with your splash screen image.

segment.source: You can enter either the name of a color or '' and the hex value of a color.
segment.target: You can enter either the name of a color or '' and the hex value of a color.

segment.source: For a list of the names of available colors, see SplashScreen element.
segment.target: For a list of the names of available colors, see SplashScreen element.

segment.source: Setting a background color for your splash screen is optional.
segment.target: Setting a background color for your splash screen is optional.

segment.source: If you don't specify a color for a UWP app, the splash screen background color defaults to a light gray (hex value 464646).
segment.target: If you don't specify a color for a UWP app, the splash screen background color defaults to a light gray (hex value 464646).

segment.source: This is the same color as the default Tile background color (see the Background Color field of the Tile Images and Logos section in the Visual Assets tab).
segment.target: This is the same color as the default Tile background color (see the Background Color field of the Tile Images and Logos section in the Visual Assets tab).

segment.source: If you don't specify a color for a Windows Phone, or set it to "transparent", then the splash screen background color will be transparent.
segment.target: If you don't specify a color for a Windows Phone, or set it to "transparent", then the splash screen background color will be transparent.

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: If your app takes a while to load, consider adding an extended splash screen.
segment.target: If your app takes a while to load, consider adding an extended splash screen.

segment.source: For step-by-step guidance, seen Create a customized splash screen.
segment.target: For step-by-step guidance, seen Create a customized splash screen.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
